sense.def: a boat with sails and sometimes an engine, used for either racing or traveling on for pleasure
dictionaryExamples: a luxury yacht
a yacht club
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The class of boat that best fits my physical condition is the one called [S]nipe, that seems to be available at your yacht club. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a small area of land next to  a house that is usually covered with grass and may have a fence around it
dictionaryExamples: We have an oak tree in our back/front yard.
She saw them playing in the yard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can you check in the yard of your house under the chair. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a unit of measurement equal to three feet or approximately 91.4 centimetres
dictionaryExamples: The garden is about 100 yards long.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm not a fitness maniac and I don't go to a shop which is 50 yards away from my house just to buy a newspaper, but if you go to school, why not go by bike[?] First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to take a deep breath with your mouth wide open, because you are  tired or bored
dictionaryExamples: I can't stop yawning - I must be tired.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am of the opinion that the morning English lessons with our teacher John are worth filming and showing for many reasons. Above all, they are enjoyable and interesting. All of us participate effectively. Nobody is yawning or feeling bored. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: yes
dictionaryExamples: "That store is a little expensive." "Yeah, it is."
"Do you want to drive?" "Yeah, sure."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yeah, try wearing black because we're gonna [get] dirty. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: a period of twelve months, especially from January 1st to December 31st
dictionaryExamples: Elaine worked in Italy for two years.
2006 was one of the worst years of my life.
last/next year
He joined the company a year ago.
This tree keeps its leaves all (the) year (round).
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She [came] from Pakistan two years ago. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu

sense.def: to be a particular age
dictionaryExamples: Her son is six years old.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is 53 years old [and] he live[s] in Madeira. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Lingala

sense.def: the part of the year, in a school or university, during which courses are taught
dictionaryExamples: the school/academic year
Jack is  now in his final/first/second year at the University of Chicago.
my freshman/sophomore/junior/senior year
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The class is ev[e]ry Friday until the end of the school year. Key English Test; A2; Croatian

sense.def: for a long time
dictionaryExamples: Hannah and I have been friends for years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had not seen him for years. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hungarian

sense.def: to shout something very loudly
dictionaryExamples: Our neighbors were yelling at each other this morning.
The child yelled out in pain.
"Just get out of here!" she yelled.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Cut," yelled the director. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a loud shout
dictionaryExamples: Suddenly there was a loud yell from the bathroom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly a big yell came out of my throat. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: being the same color as a lemon or the sun
dictionaryExamples: a bright yellow T-shirt
It was early fall and the leaves were turning yellow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friends gave me a new ring and my grandparents gave me some beautiful pink and yellow flowers. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a yellow color
dictionaryExamples: You should wear more yellow - it looks good on you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wanna paint the room in blue and yellow. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: used to agree with something, or to give a positive answer
dictionaryExamples: "Would you like a glass of wine?" "Yes, please."
"Do you like Thai food?" "Yes, I love it."
"He's a really nice guy." "Yes, he is."
"Report to me at nine o'clock tomorrow morning." "Yes, sir."
"Have you had enough to eat?" "Yes, thank you."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yes, I can come tomorrow for dinner. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Greek

sense.def: used to show that you are listening to someone, or that you are ready to listen and to give them an answer or information
dictionaryExamples: "Dad." "Yes, what do you want, honey?"
"Yes, can I help you?"

sense.def: used when you are disagreeing with a negative statement
dictionaryExamples: "I'm not a very good cook, though." "Yes, you are - you make wonderful food!"

sense.def: on the day before today
dictionaryExamples: He called yesterday while you were out.
I saw her yesterday morning/afternoon/evening.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got your letter yesterday. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Luganda

sense.def: up until now
dictionaryExamples: I haven't spoken to her yet.
He hasn't finished yet.
"Are you ready?" "Not yet - wait a minute."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I haven't seen this film yet. Key English Test; A2; Estonian

sense.def: now or as early as this time
dictionaryExamples: I don't want to go home yet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't need it yet because my parents gave me a new computer for my birthday. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: the best or worst, etc. until now
dictionaryExamples: Of all the songs I've heard tonight, that's the best yet.
That was my worst grade yet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And that was my worst experience yet. First Certificate in English; B2; Lithuanian

sense.def: again after something has happened or been done many times before
dictionaryExamples: The bus was late yet again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's another new year and yet again the early year quietness is present... until I got these two games, Quake 3 Arena (Q3A for short) and Unreal To[u]rnament (UT for short). Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: from now and for a particular period of time in the future
dictionaryExamples: She won't be back for a long time yet.
The best is yet to come.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a fact that everybody knows that living in Poland is not easy now and it won't be for a long time yet. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: until and including this time
dictionaryExamples: I haven't heard as yet if their flight has arrived.
No ambulances had as yet managed to get across the river.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to do something about it, but as I can't imagine building anything near my beautiful house (because I'm afraid it would destroy its wonderful harmony), I have no idea as yet how to solve this problem. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: used to show that you are surprised or annoyed that something is being repeated or increased
dictionaryExamples: He's given us yet more work to do.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The awe-inspiring view of the park must not be destroyed for yet another building. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: used to say there is still a possibility that something will happen
dictionaryExamples: He may win yet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Weakened, the tunnel could yet crumble and fall at any time. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to not have done something that was expected before this time
dictionaryExamples: They have yet to make a decision.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But she had yet to inform her fiancé. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: used to connect two words, phrases, or clauses when the second part adds something surprising to the first part
dictionaryExamples: a simple yet effective exercise
I agree it's unlikely, yet she knows what she's talking about.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was huge and yet gracious. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to stop in order to allow people or other vehicles to go past before you drive on or drive into another street
dictionaryExamples: Cars must yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are special traffic lights which prefer trams if they approach a certain switch, so cars have to yield then. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to produce or provide something
dictionaryExamples: to yield a profit
The investigation yielded  results.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is to be hoped that my suggestion will be implemented and will yield immediate results. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a set of exercises for the mind and body, based on the Hindu religion
dictionaryExamples: She does yoga three times a week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We do yoga in a heated room so we sweat a lot. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a slightly sour, thick liquid made from milk with bacteria added to it, sometimes sweetened and with a fruit flavor added, and sometimes eaten plain
dictionaryExamples: natural/plain yogurt
strawberry yogurt
low-fat yogurt
I only had a yogurt  for lunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every day they eat milk, cheese, yogurt, and vegetab[l]es. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Kurdish

sense.def: used to refer to the person or people you are talking to
dictionaryExamples: You look nice.
I love you.
You're coming tonight, aren't you?
Are you two ready?
You painted that yourself? You smart girl!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you for your message. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German

sense.def: people in general
dictionaryExamples: You learn to accept these things as you get older.
You can get a driver's license when you're sixteen in some states.
Too much alcohol is bad for you.
How do you get this thing to start?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can get there by plane. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: said as a polite answer when someone thanks you for doing something
dictionaryExamples: "It was very nice of you to help." "You're welcome."

sense.def: having lived or existed for only a short time and not old
dictionaryExamples: young people/adults/children
His girlfriend is very young.
Maya is the youngest person in the family.
Angela is two years younger than Luis.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All young people who play football want go there in [the] future. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: young people generally
dictionaryExamples: His political ideas appeal  to the young.
I have nothing against miniskirts, but I think they're strictly for the young.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In general, kids and teenagers are, at home, allowed to do almost anything they want, [which] sometimes put[s] parents in a very difficult position when trying to [e]stablish rules in order to limit the freedom of the young. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a young person, especially an older child
dictionaryExamples: He talked to the youngsters about the dangers of drugs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Like many other nations worldwide, with mastering much more knowledge and skills of information technology than [the] elder group of people, it is not surprising that Chinese youngsters learn more than their previous generations did about what is happening around the world. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: belonging or relating to the person or group of people being spoken or written to
dictionaryExamples: Is this your bag?
It's not your fault.
Your mother is driving me crazy.
What's your problem?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like your food. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: belonging or relating to people generally
dictionaryExamples: Of course you want the best for your children.
Garlic is good for your blood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Riding [a] bicycle is a good [way of maintaining] personal fitness and doesn't harm your health either. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: used to show that something belongs to or is connected with the person or group of people being spoken or written to
dictionaryExamples: Is this pen yours?
Unfortunately, my legs aren't as long as yours.
I have something of yours.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My bicycle is bro[k]en. Can you lend me yours? Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used at the end of formal letters when you know the name of the person you are writing to
dictionaryExamples: Yours sincerely, Maya Johnson
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to ask Tom for the [work] I will miss. Yours sincerely, Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the reflexive form of the pronoun "you"
dictionaryExamples: Be careful with that knife or you'll cut yourself!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that you could choose a partner to talk about what you usually do in your free time and the last thing was to describe yourself in front of the class. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: alone or without anyone else's help
dictionaryExamples: We didn't mean to leave you all by yourself.
Can you lift it by yourself?
Did you make the dress yourself?
You can do that yourself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is difficult to g[et] there by yourself. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: used to give special emphasis to the subject of the sentence
dictionaryExamples: If you yourself ever need help, would you know where to get it?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are thinking of taking it up yourself always do [a] warm-up exercise before you run, don't go too fast at the beginning, and don't overdo it. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: used when both the subject and object of the verb are "you," and "you" is also being used to refer to people generally
dictionaryExamples: You tell yourself everything's all right, but you know it really isn't.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You help yourself by doing some exercise. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: young people generally
dictionaryExamples: the youth of today
a youth club
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally I decided to join a new youth club in my town. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: the period of time when someone is young
dictionaryExamples: I was a fairly good football player in my youth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I played several kinds of sports during my youth, but now I am not a member of any club. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish
